facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1333 of 1967 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1333  N  of 1967. 3 05 From the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal arises from Delhi High Court judgment dated November 25, 1966 in Regular First Appeals Nos. 89-D and 104-D of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and Decree dated the 25th November, 1966 of the Delhi High Court in Regular First Appeals Nos. 89-D and 104-D of 1956. S. Desai, Ravinder Bana, O. P. Rana and Uma Mehta, for the appellants.

facts.text: Suit No. 282 of 1954 instituted by plaintiff appellant for declaration that he continued as General Manager and termination inoperative, claiming Rs. 37,352.30 arrears or alternatively Rs. 1,63,820 as bonus, gratuity etc.

anchor.surface_text: both arising from Suit No. 282 of 1954 instituted by the plaintiff appellant for a declaration that he companytinued to be the General Manager of the Fire Insurance Company in question and that the purported termination of his services was inoperative, and claiming a sum of Rs. 37,352.30 from the defendant on account of his arrears of pay, etc., or in the alternative, for a sum of Rs. 1,63,820/- as money due to him by way of bonus, gratuity, etc., as detailed in the plaint.

facts.text: Respondent Company filed Suit No. 306 of 1954 for recovery of Rs. 1,10,000 and was granted decree for Rs. 5,759/9/6.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Company had filed a suit against the appellant for the recovery of Rs. 1,10,000/- being Suit NO. 306 of 1954 in which the Company was granted a decree for Rs. 5,759/9/6 with proportionate companyts.

facts.text: Regular First Appeal No. 89-D of 1956 was the Company's appeal against decree of Rs. 73,936/15/9 in favour of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Regular First Appeal No. 89-D of 1956 was the Companys appeal against the award of decree for Rs. 73,936/15/9 passed in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: Regular First Appeal No. 104-D of 1956 was appellant's appeal against rejection of other claims.

anchor.surface_text: Regular First Appeal No. 104-D of 1956 was the appellants appeal against the rejection of his other claims in his suit.

facts.text: High Court dismissed RFA 88-D and 104-D but partially allowed RFA 89-D.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed First Appeals No. 88-D of 1956 and 104- D, of 1956 but partially allowed First Appeal No. 89-D of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant appointed as Secretary of respondent Company on October 16, 1942 with pay Rs. 1,000 per month free of income tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was appointed as the Secretary of the respondentCompany on October 16, 1942. His pay was fixed at Rs. 1,000/p.m. free of income tax.

facts.text: Appellant was later promoted as General Manager of the Company.

anchor.surface_text: Later on, he was promoted as the General Manager of the Company.

facts.text: On November 21, 1953, appellant sent application for leave to Chairman, no reply received.

anchor.surface_text: On November 21, 1953, the appellant sent an application for leave to the Chairman of the Board of Directors but numberreply was received by him.

facts.text: On December 16, 1953, appellant sent another application for 8 months leave.

anchor.surface_text: He thereafter sent another application for 8 months leave on the 16th of December, 1953.

facts.text: On December 17, 1953, appellant received telegram from Chairman stating services terminated and to stop attending office.

anchor.surface_text: On December 17, 1953, the appellant received a telegram from the Chair- man of the Board of Directors stating-that the services of the appellant had been terminated by the Company and that he should-stop attending the office.

facts.text: Appellant received registered letter from Chairman to same effect as telegram.

anchor.surface_text: A registered letter to the same effect from the Chairman was also received by him.

facts.text: Appellant alleged services not validly terminated and he continued as General Manager.

anchor.surface_text: The allegation of the appellant in the plaint was that his services had number been validly terminated by the respondent- Company and that he still companytinued. as the General Manager of the Company

facts.text: Appellant claimed alternatively 18 months salary as notice period.

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative, the appellant claimed, among other things, 18 months salary as due to him on the basis that he was entitled to 18 months numberice before terminating his services.

facts.text: Respondent contended Chairman validly terminated services on December 17, 1953 pursuant to Board resolution on December 16, 1953, confirmed on December 23, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In the written statement, the respondent-Company companytended that the Chairman validly terminated the services of the appellant on December 17, 1953 in pursuance to a resolution passed by the Board of Directors on the 16th, and that subsequently, that resolution and the action of the Chairman terminating the services had been companyfirmed by a meeting of the Board of Directors held on December 23, 1953

facts.text: Respondent contended appellant entitled to only one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-Company also companytended that the appellant was in numberevent etitled to 18 months numberice as claimed by him but only to one months numberice and, therefore, he was entitled to get only one months salary in lieu of numberice under that. head.

facts.text: Trial court found Board meeting on December 16, 1953 valid and termination valid; alternatively ratified on December 23, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt found that the meeting of the Board of Directors held on December 16, 1953 was valid, that the services of the appellant were validly terminated by telegram and letter of the Chairman dated December 17, 1953 addressed to the appellant, that even if it be assumed that the meeting of the Board of Directors held on December 16, 1953 was irregular, the resolution of the Board of Directors terminating the services of the appellant on the 16th and the action of the Chairman in actually terminating the services were ratified by the Board of Directors by its resolution of December 23, 1953

facts.text: Trial court held rules Exhibits D-3 and D-4 govern, entitling one month's notice; if not bound, 12 months notice.

anchor.surface_text: it further held that the rules framed by the Company, namely, exhibits D-3 and D-4 would govern the appellant and that he was entitled, under clause  6  of exhibit D-3 only to one months numberice for terminating his services although the Court found that if the appellant was number bound by the rules, he would have been entitled to 12 months numberice before the termination of his services.

facts.text: High Court confirmed trial court's findings.

anchor.surface_text: The findings of the trial companyrt in these respects were companyfirmed in appeal by the High Court.

facts.text: No notice of Board meeting on December 16, 1953 given to Director Mr. B. P. Khaitan, who was not present.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt found that one of the Directors, viz., Mr. B. P. Khaitan, was number given numberice of the meeting of the Board of Directors held on December 16, 1953, and that he was number present at the meeting when the resolution to terminate the services of the appellant was passed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held meeting of December 16, 1953 invalid due to no notice to all directors including Khaitan.

anchor.surface_text: Now, it cannot be disputed that numberice to all the Directors of a meeting of the Board of Directors was essential for the validity of any resolution passed at the meeting and that as, admittedly, numbernotice was given to Mr. Khaitan, one of the Directors of the Company, the resolution passed terminating the services of the appellant was invalid.

facts.text: Article 109 of Articles of Association requires at least 72 hours notice in writing to every Director.

anchor.surface_text: Article 109 of the Articles of Association of the Company provides as follows --- When meeting to be companyvened-A Director may at any time summon meeting of the Directors by serving every Director with at least 72 hours numberice in writing, through the officer of the Company authorized to receive such numberice who shall arrange to companyvene the meeting.

facts.text: Board meeting on December 23, 1953 confirmed minutes of December 16 meeting and ratified Chairman's action of termination.

anchor.surface_text: The agenda of the meeting of the Board of Directors held on December 23, 1953 shows that one item of business was the companyfirmation of the minutes of the meeting of the Directors held on December 16, 1953. The companyfirmation of the minutes of the meeting of the Directors held on December 16, 1953, would number in any way show that the Board of Directors adopted the resolution to terminate the services of the appellant passed on December 16, 1953. ... resolution of the Board of Directors to companyfirm the action of the Chairman

facts.text: Supreme Court held ratification by Board on December 23, 1953 validates termination effective from December 17, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Even if it be assumed that the, telegram and the letter terminating the services of the appellant by the Chairman was in pursuance to the invalid resolution of the Board of Directors passed on December 16, 1953 to terminate his services, it would number follow that the action of the Chairman companyld number be ratified in a regularly companyvened meeting of the Board of Directors. ... Ratification would always relate back to the date of the act ratified and so it must be held that the services of the appellant were validly terminated on December 17, 1953.

facts.text: Supreme Court held company rules Exhibits D-3 and D-4 bind appellant, providing one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court found that the rules of the Company, viz., exhibits D-3 and D-4 were binding on the appellant and that rule 6 of exhibit D-3 which provides for one months numberice in case of termination of services of all employees would apply to the appellant as well. The High Court companyfirmed that finding.

facts.text: Appellant relied on company rules for computation of bonus, provident fund etc.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, the appellant himself has relied upon these rules for the purpose of companyputation of the amount due to him on account of bonus, provident fund, etc.

concepts.interpretation: Ratification by a validly convened board meeting of the Chairman's unauthorized termination action (pursuant to invalid resolution) validates it retrospectively, relating back to the date of the act (December 17, 1953). Confirmation of minutes does not equate to adopting or ratifying the resolution.

anchor.surface_text: The confirmation of the minutes of the meeting of the Directors held on December 16, 1953, would not in any way show that the Board of Directors adopted the resolution to terminate the services of the appellant passed on December 16, 1953. It only shows that the Board passed the minutes of the proceedings of the meeting held on December 16, 1953.

holdings.text: Notice to all Directors is essential for the validity of any resolution passed at a Board meeting; as no notice was given to Mr. B. P. Khaitan, the resolution passed on December 16, 1953 terminating the services of the appellant was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Now, it cannot be disputed that notice to all the Directors of a meeting of the Board of Directors was essential for the validity of any resolution passed at the meeting and that as, admittedly, no notice was given to Mr. Khaitan, one of the Directors of the Company, the resolution passed terminating the services of the appellant was invalid. Article 109 of the Articles of Association

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Article 109 requiring 72 hours written notice to every director and Halsbury's Laws confirming notice essential; undisputed fact of no notice to Khaitan.

holdings.text: Confirmation of minutes of the December 16, 1953 meeting does not amount to adoption or ratification of the termination resolution passed therein.

anchor.surface_text: Then, the question for consideration is, what is the effect of the confirmation of the minutes of the meeting of the Board of Directors held on December 16, 1953 and the action of the Chairman in terminating the services of the appellant by his telegram and letter dated December 17, 1953, in pursuance to the invalid

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual distinction: confirming minutes approves accuracy of record of proceedings, not substantive adoption of resolutions.

holdings.text: The Board resolution on December 23, 1953 confirming the Chairman's action in terminating services by telegram and letter dated December 17, 1953 constitutes ratification of that action.

anchor.surface_text: But the resolution of the Board of Directors to confirm the action of the Chairman to terminate the services of the appellant by his telegram and letter dated December 17, 1953, would show that the Board ratified the action of the Chairman.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agenda and resolution explicitly confirm Chairman's action, distinct from mere minutes confirmation.

holdings.text: Ratification of the Chairman's termination action by the validly convened Board meeting on December 23, 1953 relates back to the date of the act (December 17, 1953), rendering the termination valid from that date notwithstanding initial invalidity.

anchor.surface_text: Even if it be assumed that the, telegram and the letter terminating the services of the appellant by the Chairman was in pursuance to the invalid resolution of the Board of Directors passed on December 16, 1953 to terminate his services, it would not follow that the action of the Chairman could not be ratified in a regularly convened meeting of the Board of Directors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard doctrine of ratification applies to unauthorized acts done on behalf of company; ratification by competent body (full Board) validates retrospectively.

holdings.text: The appellant was not entitled to the declaration that he continued as General Manager or to arrears of pay claimed on that basis.

anchor.surface_text: Ratification would always relate back to the date of the act ratified and so it must be held that the services of the appellant were validly terminated on December 17, 1953. The appellant was not entitled to the declaration prayed for by him and the trial court as well as the High Court was right in dismissing the claim.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from valid termination via ratification; lower courts correctly dismissed claim.

holdings.text: Company service rules (Exhibits D-3 and D-4), including rule 6 of D-3 providing one month's notice for termination of all employees, are binding on the appellant as General Manager.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court found that the rules of the Company, viz., exhibits D-3 and D-4 were binding on the appellant and that rule 6 of exhibit D-3 which provides for one months notice in case of termination of services of all employees would apply to the appellant as well. The High Court confirmed that finding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules expressly apply to all employees; appellant is employee; lower courts confirmed; he relied on rules for other claims (estoppel).

holdings.text: The appellant was not entitled to 18 months' or 12 months' notice; only one month's notice under the binding rules.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court found that the rules of the Company, viz., exhibits D-3 and D-4 were binding on the appellant and that rule 6 of exhibit D-3 which provides for one months notice in case of termination of services of all employees would apply to the appellant as well. The High Court confirmed that finding. The rules expressly purport to bind all the employees

holdings.reasoning_summary: Governed by specific rule 6; claims for longer notice rejected as rules bind.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbermerit in this appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: The appeal has no merit. Services were validly terminated due to ratification by the Board on December 23, 1953. Appellant bound by company rules providing for one month's notice only.
